Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 208,.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modifying an existing custody/visitation order to remove a midweek overnight and craft a schedule in the child’s best interests. Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas addresses standards for initial custody awards and removal of children from the Commonwealth, focusing on the ‘real advantage’ test and best interests in an interstate/international relocation context. It does not discuss modification of an existing visitation schedule, midweek overnights, or the specific standard for altering visitation, so it does not provide direct authority for the requested modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … [and] the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent…”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modifying an existing custody order to adjust a midweek overnight visitation schedule in the child’s best interests. Mason v. Coleman addresses a different issue: standards for relocation (removal from the Commonwealth) when parents share joint legal and physical custody under G.L. c. 208, § 30. While the case discusses the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard in the context of relocation and joint custody, it does not deal with modifying visitation schedules (such as removing a midweek overnight) and thus does not provide direct authority for the specific relief requested in the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition asks the court to modify a specific visitation schedule (removing midweek overnights) based on the child’s best interests. Rolde v. Rolde deals with an appeal from an original divorce judgment addressing custody and a reduction of visitation generally, not with a post-judgment modification of an existing schedule or the specific question of eliminating midweek overnights. While Rolde reiterates that visitation and custody decisions must serve the child’s best interests, it does not provide authority about modifying a particular component of a visitation schedule as requested in the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”

Bains v. Wadhera, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 761.raw_text: Bains v. Wadhera, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 761 (2016)
Bains v. Wadhera, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 761.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Bains v. Wadhera, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 761.case_name: Adams v. Congress Auto Insurance Agency, Inc.
Bains v. Wadhera, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 761.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a request to modify a child custody/visitation order based on the best interests of a child. Bains v. Wadhera is a Massachusetts tort/employment negligence case about misuse of confidential information and summary judgment standards; it does not involve family law, custody, visitation, or best-interests analysis. Therefore, it provides no authority for modifying a custody order or crafting a visitation schedule in a child’s best interests.
Bains v. Wadhera, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 761.relevant_excerpt: This case arose from an employee’s improper use of confidential information accessed through her workplace computer. The employee gave that information to her boy friend, who used it to intimidate a witness, Mark Adams. Adams brought this action against the employer, Congress Auto Insurance Agency, Inc. (Congress Agency or agency)… A Superior Court judge dismissed four of his five claims… The case proceeded to discovery on the remaining claim against the agency that alleged negligent failure to safeguard Adams’s personal information.

Albano v. Albano, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 373.raw_text: Albano v. Albano, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 373 (1983)
Albano v. Albano, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 373.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Albano v. Albano, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 373.case_name: City Welding & Manufacturing Co. v. Gidley-Eschenheimer Corp.
Albano v. Albano, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 373.support_reasoning: The opinion in Albano v. Albano provided in the excerpt is not a custody or family-law decision and does not address visitation schedules, midweek overnights, or the best interests of a child. It concerns breach of warranty, notice, lost profits, and damages in a commercial dispute over dump bodies and trailers. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for modifying a custody order or crafting a visitation schedule in the child’s best interests.
Albano v. Albano, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 373.relevant_excerpt: Sued for failure to pay for certain dump bodies and dump trailers, Gidley-Eschenheimer Corporation (GE) counterclaimed alleging breach of warranty. Although the manufacturing seller, City Welding and Manufacturing Co. (City), recovered on its contract claims, the primary victor was GE. A consolidated judgment in its favor included among other items, $84,500 for lost profits and damages of $8,772 based on a judgment recovered by a customer against GE. City does not contest the judge’s findings of breach of warranty or the finding of delayed delivery.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 231 (2003).proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 231 (2003).case_name: Keene v. Brigham & Women's Hospital, Inc.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 231 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of a child custody/visitation order based on the best interests of a child. Custody of Kali is a Massachusetts medical malpractice and charitable immunity case about sanctions for lost hospital records and the statutory damages cap; it does not address family law, custody, visitation schedules, or the best-interests standard. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for modifying a custody order or altering visitation.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 231 (2003).relevant_excerpt: This is a malpractice case in which a baby suffered catastrophic harm within hours of his birth at the defendant hospital. We are asked to decide whether (1) a default judgment on liability was properly entered as a sanction for the defendant’s failure to produce in discovery relevant hospital records that it admittedly had lost; (2) damages assessed against the defendant are limited by the $20,000 cap imposed by G. L. c. 231, § 85K... and (3) general damages may be awarded for loss of enjoyment of life...

Knox v. Remick, 371 Mass. 433 (1976).proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Knox v. Remick, 371 Mass. 433 (1976).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of a custody/visitation order to change a midweek overnight visit based on the child’s best interests. Knox v. Remick deals exclusively with a Probate Court’s authority to modify child support orders where a separation agreement has been incorporated into a divorce decree, and the interaction between such agreements and modifiable support orders. It does not address custody or visitation standards, nor the “best interests of the child” test in the context of parenting time, so it does not provide authority for the requested modification of visitation.
Knox v. Remick, 371 Mass. 433 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “A judge of the Probate Court for Norfolk County has reported (G. L. c. 215, § 13) a question concerning his power to modify a decree so as to require a divorced father to make increased payments for the support of his minor children… We answer the judge’s question by stating that the decree contained an order for child support and, therefore, the judge is not precluded from modifying the support order, if he determines that such a modification is appropriate in the circumstances.”

Luddington v. Otis, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 57.raw_text: Luddington v. Otis, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 572 (1997)
Luddington v. Otis, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 57.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Luddington v. Otis, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 57.case_name: Duracraft Corp. v. Holmes Products Corp.
Luddington v. Otis, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 57.support_reasoning: The opinion in Luddington v. Otis concerns Massachusetts’ anti-SLAPP statute and the scope of protection for petitioning activity, not family law or child custody. It does not discuss modification of custody orders, visitation schedules, or the ‘best interests of the child’ standard. Therefore it provides no authority for a request to modify a custody order or remove midweek overnight visitation for a child named Sophie Carter.
Luddington v. Otis, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 57.relevant_excerpt:
Accordingly, we affirm the judge’s denial of the defendants’ special motion to dismiss.

So ordered.

… We conclude that the statute imposes no condition that the defendants’ statements involve issues of public concern. … To sum up, § 59H, although not limited to matters of public concern, must be construed, for constitutional reasons, not to preclude Duracraft’s action alleging a violation of its preexisting agreement of confidentiality.

Ross v. Ross, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 595 (199.raw_text: Ross v. Ross, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 595 (1999)
Ross v. Ross, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 595 (199.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Ross v. Ross, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 595 (199.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a criminal procedure/search-and-seizure case about warrantless entry, consent, and suppression of evidence in a firearms prosecution. It does not concern family law, custody, visitation, or modification of custody/visitation orders. Therefore, it provides no authority for a request to modify a custody order or adjust visitation in the best interests of a child.
Ross v. Ross, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 595 (199.relevant_excerpt: "Police officers, to be sure, are not required to be blind. If, however, they undertake to enter a home to make a routine arrest without obtaining authority in the form of an arrest warrant, they run the risk that they blind themselves. It was error to deny the motion to suppress."

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to craft a visitation schedule that is in the best interests of Sophie Carter.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: This case concerns modification of alimony and child support based on a material change in financial circumstances, not modification of child custody or visitation. It does not discuss legal standards for altering a custody or visitation schedule, midweek overnights, or the best-interests analysis for a specific child’s visitation pattern. Therefore, it provides no authority for a request to modify an existing custody order to remove midweek overnight visitation.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment… In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion.”
